_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Helm Fertilizer Terminal, Inc.

1421 Channel Avenue

Memphis, Tennessee   38113

(901) 948-3303

                                        July 10, 2002



Risk Management Plan



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



For further information contact:

Mr. Oliver Coleman, Operations Manager



1.    Facility Policy



The Owners, management, and employees of Helm Fertilizer Terminal, Inc. (the facility) are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2.    Facility Information



General



The primary activity at the facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to

farmers and co-ops.



    Anhydrous Ammonia



Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for both direct application and for blending into mixed-grade fertilizers for crop production nutrients.  The maximum quantity stored would be 18,940,000 pounds in our main storage tank.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a barge holding 5,000,000 pounds.



Butane 



Butane is received, stored, and re-distributed under contract with a local refinery.  The maximum quantity stored is 16,742,318 pounds in our storage sphere.  The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a tank truck holding approximately 41,727 pounds.



3.    The Worst-Case Release Scenario



    Anhydrous Ammonia



The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of our main storage tank released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 18,940,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the largest storage tank at 85 percent capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 25 miles.  The alternate release scenario based on the most likely potential incident is a release from a break in a trans

fer hose.  The distance to endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 0.3 miles.



    Butane



The worst-case release scenario would be the release of the total contents of the sphere

released as a gas over 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity released would be 16,742,318

pounds, which represents the volume of the storage sphere at 85 percent capacity, as

limited by design standards.  The distance to the endpoint (estimated distance to 1 psi

overpressure) is 2.1 miles.



4.    The Five-Year Accident History



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or butane in the past five years that:



a.    have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility, nor



b.    to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



5.    The Emergency Response Program



    The facility has:



a.    a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;



b.    provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.





Risk Management Plan        Page - 2 -

Executive Summary

Helm Fertilizer Terminal, Inc.

Memphis, Tennessee   38113

July 10, 2002
